image.altText: ACT Supreme Court, Magistrates Court, building, generic

props.synopsis: It has been revealed a former student teacher on trial for sexual offences against a 15-year-old boy was sent 25 friend requests, mostly on Instagram and Snapchat, from other boys at the school where she met the alleged victim.

title.children: 'I haven't slept with him': Former trainee teacher accused of child-sex abuse told police student 'lied'

image.altText: A man and woman walk together outside a building. He wears a collared shirt and trousers.

props.synopsis: The former shop assistant admitted to slapping his young coworker on the bottom if he saw her working in the shop, when she was stacking shelves or checking inventory, or her back was turned and she did not see him coming.

title.children: Queanbeyan man avoids jail for repeatedly sexually touching teenage coworker

image.altText: Two men on bicylces strike each other with sticks.

props.synopsis: Every four years, members of the Rat Patrol mount their home-made "freak bikes" and take to Canberra's drains to compete in the Rat'lympics.Â

title.children: These 'human rats' search high and low for the perfect discarded parts to make their mutant bikes

image.altText: A sign reading "Look out Swooping bird'' with a picture of a magpie, in front of a road.

props.synopsis: Magpie nesting season is in full swing and wildlife experts want walkers and cyclists to know how best to respond to swooping birds.

title.children: 'They remember faces': What you should and shouldn't do when a magpie swoops

image.altText: An aerial view of Melbourne's south-eastern suburbs.

props.synopsis: The RBA is meeting today to hand down this year's sixth cash rate decision, but only one of Australia's four major banks expects a rate cut by the end of the year.

title.children: Hoping the RBA will cut interest rates today? Here's what the big four banks are saying

image.altText: Signs at coles and woolworths

props.synopsis: Regular customers, fed up with Coles and Woolworths' marketing tactics, have set off a chain of events that have seen Australia's biggest grocers dragged before the courts.

title.children: Why it took people power to bring Australia's two biggest supermarkets to court

image.altText: Colin Kinner, who has short brown hair and is wearing a blue collared shirt, poses for a photo next to a window

props.synopsis: A free online course aims to bust COVID misinformation and teach people how to stop the virus spreading in schools. But perhaps its greatest challenge is engaging people in the first place â particularly those who believe COVID is harmless.

title.children: Schools don't have to be hotbeds of COVID. One dad is fighting back with facts

image.altText: swans swim on a lake at sunrise

props.synopsis: Beloved native swans are particularly susceptible to a deadly strain of bird flu, according to scientists who fear for native birds if the virus hits Australian shores.

title.children: Black swan extinction possible if deadly bird flu strain arrives in Australia

image.altText: Smoke plumes coming out of a city scape.

props.synopsis: Israel's military has launched more than 800 strikes on Lebanon targeting Hezbollah after warning residents to leave areas where the terrorist group may be operating. Follow live.

title.children: Penny Wong calls for de-escalation in Lebanon as thousands flee strikes in region's deadliest day since civil war

image.altText: Three layers of seta in the back of a truck full of people looking out

props.synopsis: Thousands are fleeing Lebanon as Israel launches hundreds of air strikes, killing 492 people and wounding 1,645 more in the most deadly day of the cross-border conflict in two decades.Â

title.children: Death toll in Lebanon nears 500 as Israel launches hundreds of air strikes

image.altText: A man and woman stand handcuffed in front of a red background

props.synopsis: South-East Asian politicians have also demanded the release of five democracy activists whose executions are imminent.

title.children: 'Unspeakable acts by an unspeakable regime': Myanmar junta reportedly executes first woman since coup

image.altText: A man is pictured from behind.

props.synopsis: The credibility of the Albanese government's much vaunted wagering self-exclusion scheme BetStop has been called into question after loopholes in the system allowed a Sydney man to lose nearly $70,000 despite signing up to a lifetime ban.

title.children: BetStop was supposed to protect gambling addicts, but it didn't stop Ravi from losing nearly $70,000

image.altText: A view of the Reserve Bank of Australia with people walking by.

props.synopsis: Central banks, including the RBA, subscribe to an old economics theory that unemployment must rise in order for inflation to fall. It's one they should consign to the dustbin.

title.children: RBA relying on outdated theory about inflation and employment

image.altText: A man with a world map behind him

props.synopsis: The man accused of hiding out with a gun near Donald Trump's Florida golf course in an apparent bid to kill the former president wrote a letter months earlier describing an "assassination attempt", prosecutors say.

title.children: Ryan Routh wrote letter describing 'assassination attempt' on Trump, prosecutors say

image.altText: A man speaks at a lectern

props.synopsis: Climate Change Authority head Matt Kean says expert advice differs to what Peter Dutton says about nuclear and renewables being companions not competitors.

title.children: 'Very different advice': Climate Change Authority chair Matt Kean contradicts Dutton on nuclear power

image.altText: An illustration of a man dreaming of sleep-tracking wearables

props.synopsis: Sleep-tracking has boomed in popularity worldwide, giving researchers access to millions of hours of sleep data. When a natural disaster hits or a COVID variant spreads, they see the impact in our sleep.

title.children: Popular sleep-tracking has wired the world for study. Now the first results are in

image.altText: Tony Armstrong wearing a white T shirt and a denim jacket.

props.synopsis: Popular ABC presenter and Gold Logie nominee Tony Armstrong announces he will leave ABC News Breakfast in October. Tony will return to ABC screens in 2025 hosting a new show to be announced later.Â

title.children: Tony Armstrong announces departure from ABC News Breakfast to host new show

image.altText: A woman wearing a World Central Kitchen cap points the camera at herself, palm trees in the background

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong will call for a new international declaration for the protection of humanitarian personnel following the killing of Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom in Gaza earlier this year.

title.children: 'They can't be brave at any cost': Australia to pressure world leaders to pledge to protect aid workers

image.altText: Police officer strings up checked tape

props.synopsis: A manhunt is underway after a 32-year-old was stabbed to death in the middle of a busy inner city Sydney shopping and dining precinct.

title.children: Man stabbed to death during 'peak dinner time' in Sydney night-life precinct

image.altText: Albany Regional Prison

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest into the death of a 29-year-old prisoner in a WA facility raises concerns about addiction treatment in prisons, as a researcher says the true scale of overdoses is unknown.

title.children: Prisoner's death linked to inhaling canola oil spray as second inmate suffers suspected overdose

image.altText: Patrick Cripps kisses the Brownlow Medal on stage

props.synopsis: Carlton captain Patrick Cripps takes home his second Brownlow Medal, breaking the record for most votes received in a single AFL season in the process.

title.children: Patrick Cripps claims his second Brownlow with record-breaking vote tally

image.altText: A close up side-on shot of a brown baby penguin.

props.synopsis: At just nine months of age, Pesto is already far bigger than the adult king penguins at Melbourne's aquarium.

title.children: Calm, curious and can eat eight fish at a time â meet Pesto the Penguin

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: ASX edges up ahead of RBA's widely anticipated interest rate decision. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: ASX edges up ahead of RBA's widely anticipated interest rate decision

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: 'Red hot': PM whacks supermarkets amid ACCC action
Greens should come to the table on 'sensible' RBA reforms

image.altText: Angus Brayshaw stands in a tux holding a glass of champagne

props.synopsis: Former Melbourne player Angus Brayshaw has toasted his fellow AFL retirees at the Brownlow Medal, saying it's a relief to know there's life after football.

title.children: 'The transition is difficult': Brayshaw's Brownlow speech tugs on heartstrings

image.altText: An Indian farmer thrashes paddy to separate the grain after harvest.

props.synopsis: Australian phosphate miners are looking to boost India's food and manufacturing industries and gain a bigger foothold in the world's fastest-growing large economy.Â

title.children: As India tries to feed the world's largest population, can Australia meet its fertiliser needs?

image.altText: A silhouette of a woman standing at a window with sheer curtains. The room is dark and the atmosphere is moody.

props.synopsis: Women with disability are 40 per cent more likely to experience domestic and family violence than women without disability. Survivor-advocates and experts explain some of the ways perpetrators weaponise disability to target victims, maintain control, and conceal abuse.

title.children: How perpetrators of domestic violence weaponise disability

image.altText: Bri Lee 2024

props.synopsis: The author and journalist speaks about the fork in the road that changed her life, and why she had to step away from sexual assault advocacy.

title.children: For years, Bri Lee was a law graduate dealing with sexual assault. The next move she made was 'out of self-protection'

image.altText: A middle-aged Kurdish woman smiles at the camera in a posed but informal portrait shot.

props.synopsis: Cigdem Aslan, whose Australian passport is in the name of Lenna Aslan, was reportedly arrested at Istanbul Airport on suspicion of conducting activities for the PKK, a banned terrorist group in both TÃ¼rkiye and Australia.

title.children: Australian woman arrested in TÃ¼rkiye on suspicion of supporting banned Kurdish terror group

image.altText: Asylum seekers stare at media from behind a fence

props.synopsis: Data compiled by the Department of Home Affairs and obtained by the ABC shows the prevalence of severe mental health issues that still affect people held in Australia's immigration detention network.

title.children: Australia a 'brutal outlier' as epidemic levels of self-harm continue in immigration detention

image.altText: An SA Police vehicle with flashing lights.

props.synopsis: SA Police charges a 20-year-old disability worker with dangerous driving following a fatal crash at Hayborough, south of Adelaide on Sunday that killed a woman using a wheelchair.

title.children: Disability worker charged after fatal crash south of Adelaide

image.altText: a group of soldiers wearing camouflage stepping from the shore onto a beach

props.synopsis: As US military presence ramps up in the north, experts say one of Australia's closest Asian neighbours is growing wary that the US's expanded presence could bring rising tensions to the region.

title.children: Growing US military build-up in Australia's north concerning Indonesia

image.altText: A 120-year-old Hudswell-Clarke engine crosses a rail intersection in Ingham

props.synopsis: As some sugar mills face uncertain futures and governments tighten budgets, it is often retirees and volunteers left salvaging what they can of our cane train history.

title.children: Track by track, rail buffs fear Australia's cane train history is being erased
